Award.AwardTitle: MRI RAPID: Acquisition of a FlowCAM for Concurrent Analysis of Marine and Estuarine Hydrocarbon Particles, Microbe and Microinvertebrate Assemblages
Award.AbstractNarration: This Major Research Instrumentation award to Auburn University funds the acquisition of a water analysis system to enhance the scientific response to the Deep Horizons Oil Spill and its effects on coastal ecosystems. The overarching goal is to better understand how planktonic microinvertebrate and microbes will be affected by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Auburn researchers and their students will use the equipment throughout the upcoming year to monitor the Northern Gulf of Mexico water and its particulate and planktonic assemblages. Specific objectives of this project include 1) examining how long oil droplets persist in the water column, 2) determining the degree to which organisms accumulate oil initially and thereafter into lipid-rich regions of the body, and 3), determining the effect of the oil on invertebrate larval and protist populations. An expected result of this NSF-RAPID award is timely and critical information to inform policy and remediation efforts in response to the oil spill. Results from the studies and education efforts will be disseminated in peer-reviewed journal publications, though participation at regional and national scientific meetings, and through a range of public outreach efforts that include meetings with affected citizens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Number:          1058514

Award Title:    MRI RAPID: Acquisition of a FlowCAM for Concurrent Analysis of Marine and Estuarine Hydrocarbon Particles, Microbe and Microinvertebrate Assemblages

PI/Co-PI Name:           Anthony Moss

This grant funded the acquisition of a FlowCAM, a specialized piece of American-made piece of lab or field equipment that acts as a very high speed microscope that individually photographs microscopic plankton that can be found in aquatic and marine environments, for purposes of assessing the state of the plankton (i.e. drifting organisms) at the microscopic level of organization (from approximately 5 to 100 microns in length). Microscopic plankton are critical to the local food web and for energy flow through the environment, because they may 1) if photosynthetic algae or bacteria, capture energy and carbon from the atmosphere, which is then in turn 2) collected by a second group of organisms that eat such algae and bacteria, including larger nonphotosynthetic plankton such as copepods and the young of commercially important bivalves such as scallops, oysters, mussels, and also arthropod species such as shrimp, spiny lobster and crabs, 3) by such economically important adult oysters or scallops. In addition, 4) even larger predators such as certain ground fish (for instance flounder) eat members of the second and third groups, and they are themselves preyed upon by 5) larger fish or invertebrate animals; 6) even larger predators such as mullet eat the larger plankton species while other small to moderate sized fish such as mackerel consume the smaller fish. The larger fish species are often considered to be commercially important fishery species such as grouper, and important game fish such as pompano, cobia and amberjack. Thus the tiniest microbial plankton are critical to the health and success of much larger organisms; such tiny plankton are very hard to see, and so require a specialized instrument such as the FlowCAM to enumerate, identify and assess for health. 

For the first studies with this instrument, we have conducted experiments funded by BP (this NSF grant simply supplied the instrument) to examine the impact of anthropogenic perturbations such as the oil and dispersant used in the recent Deepwater Horizon Spill, have on plankton. We are able to assess the impact of the treatments on the plankton using the FlowCAM, which can not only detect plankton but also oil droplets in suspension, and we couple those results with other studies to precisely determine the identity and quantities of the different plankton groups. Thus, the FlowCAM contributes directly to our improved understanding of the impact of such perturbations on the environment through the plankton. We are currently (August, 2011) writing up a report on our results for dissemination in the scientific literature and at scientific meetings.

This is the first of many different applications for this very versatile instrument. The specific instrument obtained can be carried directly to the field because it has a very tough impact resistant housing, can detect the presence of living and dead planktonic material as well as oil and sediment. Because of the way it works, it additionally can see things that no other tools can easily and as rapidly see, such as intractions between different planktonic organisms and pollutants such as oil. In addition it also can detect complex groups of organisms (‘assemblages’). This instrument will help to form the basis for many future studies of marine environmental health, well beyond the current studies.
